utterances: Oh, you're just getting the brown spot.
Yeah, I was getting the dry spot.
It's a coverage problem, probably.
You're doing great, Barbara.
It is my pleasure, Guy.
To help us compare, we've called Michael Miller - he's policy director of Community Catalyst, a national healthcare advocacy group based in Boston.
Good morning, sir.
Good morning.
I think some people have compared the Massachusetts plan to car insurance - its basic idea - everybody has to have it.
Is that right?
Well, you know, that's something of an oversimplification and it stems from the fact that everyone doesn't have to have a car.
So in Massachusetts you are required to have health insurance if there is an affordable plan available for you.
Meaning that if you can afford it, you have to buy it.
If you can't afford it and if the state pays for it, then you can do it.
Is that right?
Right.
So if you're not eligible for a subsidy and your employer doesn't offer it, then there's a test to determine, okay, is there a plan available that's reasonable for you to purchase?
And if it is, then you have to buy it.
But if not, you would still be left out of the mandate.
So now as I understand it, Massachusetts is starting to put its health insurance plan into effect.
How's it going?
Massachusetts is doing great, I think.
Massachusetts is off to a great start.
They've started enrolling people in subsidized coverage and we've seen enrollments, I think, going well without huge problems.
I think that the mountain gets progressively steeper as they go forward, because the first stage was basically for folks who were completely subsidized, no premiums.
And then now we're in the stage where we're enrolling people who have sliding scale subsidies and soon we'll be talking about enrolling people who don't have any subsidies.
So each of those is another hurdle to get over.
How are you going to know if this thing is completely succeeding?
Well, that's hard to say for sure, but certainly, obviously, we judge by the number of uninsured.
We judge by whether there's a lot of bad debt - so that people who have insurance, are they really insured or are they underinsured?
And we judge also by political acceptance; do people feel that they are being asked to do something that's reasonable, or do they feel that the mandate is unduly burdensome and unfair?
Are you also going to have to judge by insurance rates, because if everybody is insured, shouldn't that mean that other people's insurance rates should go down?
I mean, the people who already had insurance, their rates should go down a little bit, or at least not rise as much?
Well I think that that's absolutely right.
It would be nice to see rates go down, although I'm not sure anyone expects that, but certainly a slower rate of increase.
And if you had one piece of advice to give to other states, like California now, considering this plan, what would it be?
Well, just looking at what I've seen of California so far, as the debate goes forward there, I would say that they need to do some more thinking about affordability.
I think in Massachusetts that conversation really is still ongoing.
And what I've seen from Governor Schwarzenegger's plan, you know, that's an area that they might need to address more fully.
Because if plans aren't affordable, and they're not reasonably comprehensive, I think that the mandate has a great likelihood of failing that last test - the political test.
Okay, Mr. Miller.
Thanks very much.
You're welcome.
Michael Miller is policy director for Community Catalyst, a national health advocacy group based in Boston, Massachusetts.
At Camp David today, President Bush holds the second of two days of meetings on Iraq.
The President said yesterday that the success of the Iraqi government depends on its ability to provide security and basic services.
And he wants to make sure the fledgling Baghdad regime can do that.
NPR's Don Gonyea reports.
the death of al-Qaida's Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, and the announcement that the final key positions in the Iraqi cabinet had been filled.
Yesterday morning, the President spoke briefly with reporters in a conference room at Camp David.
He introduced U.S.
Ambassador Zalmay Khalilzad who was in Baghdad, but who joined through a video teleconference.
President GEORGE W.
BUSH: We left off when you were talking about the way forward in Iraq and the inception of this new government.
Khalilzad repliedâ€¦
We have the major success in bringing about a government of national unity in Iraq, a government in which all communities are represented.
We got the Prime Minister, who is a very much hands, a good chief executive with good abilities to make decisions, prioritizing what is needed in terms of what Iraq must do.
The White House is using this war council at Camp David, scheduled to continue today, to demonstrate the U.S.
commitment to Iraq, even as polls in the U.S.
show widespread discontent with the war and the President's handling of the mission.
The White House says the meeting will continue today with a satellite hookup linking Iraqi Prime Minister Maliki and his cabinet, with U.S.
officials at the presidential retreat.
President Bush looked ahead to that session.
We'll be meeting with the new government via CIVICS(ph).
And that will be a very interesting experience for all of us to be able to talk to our respective counterparts.
Going into yesterday's meeting, there was a lot of discussion about comments Sunday by General George Casey, who is in charge of the Iraq mission.
He says a draw down of U.S.
troop levels could begin in just months.
The White House, however, did not want that to be the focus of coverage of this summit, so the President downplayed the issue.
Whatever we do will be based upon the conditions on the ground.
And whatever we do will be toward a strategy of victory.
And then the next words were we think we found Shawn.
We're 95 percent sure we found Shawn and that he's alive.
And those were the sweetest words I've ever heard in my life.
Water conservation, probably, for the last 10 years or so - and I do like it 'cause it's a positive thing that you can pass on information - help people save water - help them save money, too.
Silva is one of only four full-time water cops for a city of almost 4 million people.
There are two part-timers, and the city plans to hire three more.
By comparison, Los Angeles has 570 full-time parking enforcement officers.
Jim McDaniel is a senior assistant general manager at LADWP.
And he says those numbers are just fine.
I look at it as - not parking, but I think of it as kind of, like, people running red lights and stuff.
You don't need to have a police officer at every stoplight to make people not run red lights.
You know, have enough people out there so that people know - yeah, there are people watching, but we just know what the right thing to do is.
McDaniel says that of L.A.'s $30 million water conservation budget, only three percent is spent on enforcement.
Eighty-five percent goes toward incentive programs.
Rebates for plumbing fixtures, high-efficiency toilets, free low-flow shower heads - We have very generous rebates for low water use appliances.
We're actually paying people $3 a square foot to take out their lawns.
A lot of care - a little stick.
Is that good?
Spending the least on enforcement makes sense to me.
I don't know that spending a lot more would do much better.
That's Alison Ledgerwood, a psychologist who studies social influence at the University of California, Davis.
Ledgerwood says punishment really only works if it does several things.
Punishment works if you have a bunch of conditions in place, including people are pretty sure they would get caught.
The punishment has to be consistently applied.
It has to be perceived as fair.
And the punishment has to be strong enough to deter the behavior.
In a city as big as L.A., doing all of that would be tough.
And LA's current incentive-heavy approach is working.
The DWP says LA's water use has gone down by 17 percent over the last three years.
Hilda Blanco directs the Center for Sustainable Cities at the University of Southern California.
She says the city is doing well, but it could do more through social pressure.
The nudge approach.
Blanco points to Atlanta.
In the late '90s, that city began sending water bills that showed more than just your own water use.
It said your own total consumption was so much, your neighbor's average consumption was this much, and finally, you consume more water than let's say 73 percent of your neighbors.
That tactic cut water use by almost five percent.
L.A.
hasn't tried something like that yet.
But their existing restrictions are already more strict than the new ones the state put in place this week.
Even so, Rick Silva, the water cop, is just going to give the gardener he caught a flier.
And this will let you know the watering days that they should be watering because it's different for even and odd-numbered addresses.
Hand-watering is allowed any day.
No fine until he's caught three times.
Soon, L.A.
will distribute door hangers for people to post on their neighbor's houses when they see them violating water rules - a different kind of social pressure, shame.
Sam Sanders, NPR News.
